data.text:
As a reminder the Photo Series project was assigned last week. It is due on Tuesday, April 16 at the start of class.

This project asks that you to develop a conceptually driven photographic series in either black and white or color (do not mix the two). Your project can be one of two things: Thematic or Narrative.

The grading criteria will consist of:

How well your photographs communicate your idea(s).

Technique: Manual photography use – depth of field, shutter speed, exposure, etc.

Development of the Digital Negatives

Aesthetics: composition, framing, vantage point, etc.

Presentation of project

Written statement

Print quality

Participation in the critique

Requirements:

A minimum of 10 photographs is required for this project. A max of 20 can be submitted.

Submit JPEG or TIFF files only. RAW files will not be accepted.

Your project should have a title.

In addition, a typed statement (minimum two paragraphs) is required). Please submit this as a Word Doc or PDF.

In addition, one print (paper will be supplied).

Please refer to the full guidelines: Project 3 Photographic Series Purchase

If you are confused/want an opinion about which direction to go in – talk to me or email me ASAP.

During this week’s class (April 9) we will be discussing PRINTING and NEGATIVE SCANNING. Paper will be supplied. Please bring some negatives to scan.

The remainder of class time will be devoted time in the lab to let you work on your Photo Series, print, scan, etc.

This slideshow requires JavaScript.

Visit the Gordon Parks Foundation in Pleasantville, NY. See either below exhibit and make a photograph as a response to the exhibition. Email me the photograph as a JPEG or TIFF. This opportunity is extended until the last class of the semester. 10 POINTS.

Mission Statement: The Gordon Parks Foundation permanently preserves the work of Gordon Parks, makes it available to the public through exhibitions, books, and electronic media and supports artistic and educational activities that advance what Gordon described as “the common search for a better life and a better world.”

The Gordon Parks Foundation

48 Wheeler Avenue, 1st Floor

Pleasantville, New York, 10570

Tel: (914) 238-2619

Admission is free. Link to hours.

A GREAT DAY: ON VIEW UNTIL MARCH 29

Link to exhibit and video

In 1958, Art Kane (1925–1995) photographed fifty-seven jazz musicians spilling off a brownstone stoop in Harlem for an Esquire magazine issue about the evolution of the genre. Since the Harlem Renaissance, the neighborhood had been a notable center of the uniquely American sound of jazz. As his photograph—commonly referred to as “A Great Day in Harlem”—ingrained itself in our collective memory, countless “Great Day” homages were created to record other historic gatherings: A Great Day in Hollywood, . . . Philadelphia, . . . Kansas City, . . . Jersey, . . . Saint Paul, . . . Houston, . . . Spanish Harlem, and a Dutch version, A Great Day in Haarlem, among others.

Gordon Parks (1912–2006) visited this theme four decades after Kane, showcasing the importance of the brownstone at 17 East 126th Street. In 1995, Life magazine assembled ten of the twelve surviving musicians from Kane’s picture, and Parks photographed them standing where they had stood in 1958. The decrepit facade of the brownstone overwhelmed the silhouettes of the few elderly musicians, representing the end of the “Golden Age” of jazz that Kane had documented. The graffiti and cinder-blocked door and windows remind the viewer not just of the deleterious effects of time on people and structures, but of the evolution and gentrification of Harlem and the culture and music born from it. Three years after the Life photo, XXL magazine tapped Parks to return to 126th Street to photograph 177 hip-hop artists, producers, and influencers, who overflowed the stoop of number 17 to the two stoops on either side. The youthful bodies of a new genre’s golden age overtook the dilapidated brownstone, reclaiming the space for the next generation.

At the twentieth anniversary of A Great Day in Hip-Hop—and the sixtieth anniversary of Kane’s original photo—17 East 126th Street has been lovingly restored and continues to tell the story of the shifting look, feel, and sound of Harlem.

JAMEL SHABAZZ: HONOR AND DIGNITY: APRIL 5 – JULY 22

Artist Reception Friday, April 5th ● 6 to 8 p.m. (Remarks 7 p.m.)

Jamel Shabazz is one of New York’s most innovative street photographers. For the past forty years, he has documented the cultural vibrancy of the city’s black and brown communities. This exhibition offers a concise view of Shabazz’s wide-ranging work, from photographs of musicians and teenagers radiating with hip-hop style to members of the military and participants in religious and political gatherings.

Born and raised in Brooklyn, Shabazz began photographing the streets of New York in 1980. The city was emerging from a challenging period: in the late 1970s, its economy was faltering, crime was on the rise, and many neighborhoods were physically deteriorating. Where some saw danger or decay, Shabazz saw an opportunity: to positively represent the vibrant street life and culture of black and Latinx communities. He has documented urban life ever since, “giving a voice to the often invisible and voiceless,” as he has said of his mission.

Shabazz’s keenly observed images—his attention to the details of fashion, deportment, and style, for example—celebrate the self-possession and cultural complexity of his subjects. Considering himself a social documentarian, he carries on the tradition of James Van Der Zee, Gordon Parks, and Leonard Freed, photographers who used their cameras to combat discrimination and stereotypes by illuminating the vitality and pride of their subjects, no matter the hardships or prejudice they faced.

“As a socially conscious photographer, I strive to create images that show reality, provoke thought, and at the same time contribute to a visual record of time and history,” Shabazz has said of the social and political basis of his work. In the end, he sees the portrayal of the “dignity and honor of a people” as central to his artistic viewpoint and to “what I want my work to represent now and for future generations.” The work in this exhibition exemplifies this objective, shaped by the intelligence, grace, and empathy of Jamel Shabazz’s singular vision.

As a reminder, tomorrow you should arrive to class, camera in tow with self-portraits (on memory cards or external flash drives).

You have been asked to make two self-portraits: a passport style self-portrait (ideally – head and shoulders against a white or neutral colored wall) and a second, more creative, thought-out self-portrait. NO SELFIES, (Also, see horrific articles about selfie related injuries and death statistics at the bottom of this post).

During class we will have open lab time to look/edit in Adobe Camera Raw/Bridge and process Raw Files before delving into Photoshop to work on the Zombie exercise.

Please check out articles at the bottom of this post. Moving ahead, they may be inspirational, interesting, or at the very least, give you some more insight into the selfie vs. the self portrait.

Lastly, responses for the Nature of Photographs are due tomorrow.

Please find a downloadable PDF of the assignment below:

Reading Response_Shore Purchase

The Un-Selfie: Taking Back the Self-Portrait

THE NEW YORKER: SEEING THEMSELVES: PHOTOGRAPHERS’ SELF-PORTRAITS

By Jessie Wender

“There’s been a lot of talk about selfies recently. The Oxford Dictionaries named “selfie” the word of the year for 2013, and “Museum Selfie Day,” last month, encouraged museumgoers to take creative selfies in front of art. But what distinguishes a selfie from an artist’s self-portrait? A smartphone and a Tinder account is the easy answer, but, in general, we ask more from a self-portrait than we do from a selfie: more consideration, more composition, more psychological insight and aesthetic care. From family photographs to annual staged series and quirky snaps captured in a street windows, here is a selection of my favorite self-portraits.”

SEEING THEMSELVES: PHOTOGRAPHERS’ SELF-PORTRAITS

SELFIE GONE WRONG: WOMAN WHO CROSSED ZOO BARRIER TO TAKE PICTURE NEAR JAGUAR SURVIVES ATTACK

https://www.newsweek.com/woman-who-crossed-zoo-barrier-take-selfie-jaguar-survives-attack-1357551

More than 250 people worldwide have died taking selfies, study finds

https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/10/03/more-than-250-people-worldwide-have-died-taking-selfies-study-finds/?utm_term=.f26367b9dd5d

As a reminder, the Portrait or Landscape project is due tomorrow at 8:30 am. This project is worth a total of 100 possible points.

This means you must be ready to present your work at 8:30 am (having prior sent the project to marisa.scheinfeld@purchase.edu via www.wetransfer.com or by bringing JPEG or TIFF files on a flash/external hard drive.

No RAW files are acceptable as submitted work. Photographs should be processed in Camera Raw and saved as either JPEGS or TIFFs. Please remember part of your grade is to label your file name with the type of portrait or landscape (i.e.: environmental portrait.tif or goldenhour.jpg.). All files should be in one folder with your name on it.

A critique will occur at the beginning of class. Arrival on time is also part of your grade as is critique participation.

Please see the full project guidelines here: Portrait or Landscape Assignment Guide

As mentioned in our previous class, Quiz 1 will also occur sometime tomorrow.

If you have any questions or concerns, email me.

In lieu of class being cancelled tomorrow, there are two power points you will be responsible for covering on your own, along with an assignment called 100 Photos, due next week, February 19.

The first powerpoint will go over digital file formats and the second will look at the various steps to take and factors to consider when making a photograph all the while considering the principles of design and basic photographic terminology.

Please navigate to “Weekly Schedule” and “Session #3” to find the day’s material.

On that page you will be able to download two power points:

Introduction to Camera Raw

2. Photographic Composition & Elements of Design/ Learning to Make Photographs (Note: Please skip the 18-minute video in this Power Point entitled Henri Cartier-Bresson: The Decisive Moment‬. We will watch this together in another class.

After spending some time going over each powerpoint, make sure your camera is set to capture images in the RAW file format and download the PDF of the homework assignment entitled “100 Photos.” Your assignment is to complete Parts I and II on the PDF. Parts III – IV will occur in class next week.

I expect you to show up next week with your camera in tow and both the Manual 101 assignment (3 exposed photographs of one scene from last week) AND the above “100 Photos” assignment on your memory cards.

Remember, shoot the 100 Photos assignment in RAW mode. This is essential as it will lead us into the digital lab next week where we will open up Photoshop’s image editing program called Camera RAW (which only processes RAW files). It is a fantastic and powerful program specifically designed for photographic editing and we will spend much of the class learning the basics of the program using the images shot from the 100 Photos assignment.

If you have ANY questions or concerns while going over the power points, setting your camera on RAW capture, or the homework itself, please email me.
